conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than or less than 100 meters, we need to calculate the area under the velocity-time (v-t) graph from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds.
The area under the curve represents the distance traveled.
The graph shows velocity (v) on the y-axis and time (t) on the x-axis.
From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, the velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s.

premise: The area under the curve from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds can be approximated as the area of a triangle since the velocity increases linearly.
conclusion: The formula for the area of a triangle is: Area = 1/2 × base × height.

premise: The base is the time interval (10 seconds), and the height is the final velocity (20 m/s).
The actual curve is not a straight line but slightly concave, meaning the velocity increases a bit more slowly than linear initially and then more rapidly.
conclusion: This concavity suggests that the actual area under the curve is slightly less than the area of the triangle.

premise: The calculated area of the triangle is 100 m.
conclusion: The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is slightly less than 100 meters.
